pullRequest.body:
We add `IsPrimitiveRoot.exists_pow_or_neg_mul_pow_of_isOfFinOrder`: If `x` is a root of unity (spelled as `IsOfFinOrder x`) in an `n`-th cyclotomic extension of `â„š`, where `n` is odd, and `Î¶` is a primitive `n`-th root of unity, then there exists `r < n` such that `x = Î¶^r` or `x = -Î¶^r`.

From flt-regular

- [x] depends on: #11235

---

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by Ruben-VandeVelde.

> We add `IsPrimitiveRoot.exists_neg_pow_mul_pow_of_pow_eq_one`: if `x` is a `k`-th root of unity in an `n`-th cyclotomic extension, where `n` is odd, and `Î¶` is a primitive `n`-th root of unity, then there exist `r` such that `x = (-1)^r * Î¶^r`.

Please update the top post, since the name `IsPrimitiveRoot.exists_neg_pow_mul_pow_of_pow_eq_one` is no longer part of the diff.

maintainer merge
LGTM now.

Thanks!

maintainer merge

How about
```suggestion
  have : a.totient = 1 := by linarith [Nat.totient_pos han]
  cases' Nat.totient_eq_one_iff.1 this with h h <;> simp [h]
```
Would it be easier to make `k : PNat` directly?
Ah, we have `[PNat.lcm](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/PNat/Prime.html#PNat.lcm)`. Let me see.
Yes, it's better, thanks!

And like this?
```suggestion
  obtain âŸ¨xu, rflâŸ© := hx.isUnit hppos
```
Does this need `_root_`?
It doesn't.

```suggestion
  rcases totient_eq_one_iff.mp <| le_antisymm ha <| totient_pos han with rfl | rfl <;> norm_num
```
(We are in namespace `Nat` here, I think, so the `Nat.` prefix can be removed.)

We should add a lemma
```lean
lemma IsCyclic.exists_ofOrder_eq_natCard {G : Type*} [Group G] (h : IsCyclic G) : 
    âˆƒ g : G, orderOf g = Nat.card G := by
  obtain âŸ¨g, hgâŸ© := h.exists_generator
  use g
  rw [â† Nat.card_zpowers g, (Subgroup.eq_top_iff' (Subgroup.zpowers g)).mpr hg]
  exact (Nat.card_congr (Equiv.Set.univ G).symm).symm
```
for this purpose.
Good idea!

Mmm, actually the problem remains: we need to prove that the cardinality of the set of `k`-th roots of unity is `k`, and for these we need a primitive `k`-th root, so I don't see how to simplify the proof using your `exists_ofOrder_eq_natCard` (that is anyway a good result to have).

Ah, OK; right! But you should be able to use the given elements to show that the order of `rootsOfUnity k L` is a multiple of both `p` and `q`, so of `k` (without working with `Subtype`s, just by using `xu` and `yu` and their orders in the unit group), and on the other hand, divides `k` by general facts.
We have [card_rootsOfUnity](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/RootsOfUnity/Basic.html#card_rootsOfUnity), which gives `â‰¤`, but this should be good enough...
This is essentially what I already do, but it can be more direct. I will have a look tomorrow, thanks for idea!
It's done. There is still a bit of friction when moving elements from roots of unity, to units, to the field, but it is slightly better.
Can you use [rootsOfUnity_le_of_dvd](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/RootsOfUnity/Basic.html#rootsOfUnity_le_of_dvd) to simplify this proof?
Not that much (because of something annoying about `PNat`, you probably don't want to know), but a little golf was possible, thanks!

```suggestion
  have hxuord : orderOf (âŸ¨xu, hxmemâŸ© : rootsOfUnity k L) = p := by
    rw [Subgroup.orderOf_mk, â† orderOf_units, hx.eq_orderOf]
  have hyuord : orderOf (âŸ¨yu, hymemâŸ© : rootsOfUnity k L) = q := by
    rw [Subgroup.orderOf_mk, â† orderOf_units, hy.eq_orderOf]
```
This is a bit more direct.

```suggestion
  rw [show Î¶ ^ (r % â†‘n) = Î¶ ^ r from (IsPrimitiveRoot.eq_orderOf hÎ¶).symm â–¸ pow_mod_orderOf .., hr]
  rcases Nat.even_or_odd r with (h | h) <;> simp [h.neg_one_pow]
```

This looks slightly strange to me: existence of a primitive p'th root and a primitive q'th root is the same as existence of a primitive `Nat.lcm p q`th root, so this theorem feels like it's the composite of two theorems, one saying that and the other saying that if there exists a primitive x'th root then (change all `Nat.lcm p q` to `x`). And why do you demand the primitive roots rather than just asserting their existence? They don't play any role in the other hypotheses or conclusion. 

I ran into this phenomenon of not knowing how best to say "there are n n'th roots of unity in this field" in the cyclotomic PR as well. You have asked for an explicit primitive root, and I don't like this because the conclusion doesn't depend on the choice of primitive root; indeed one reason I wrote the cyclotomic PR was because the already existing `IsPrimitiveRoot.autToPow` asked for an explicit primitive root whereas the cyclotomic character doesn't need such a choice, existence will do. But in the cyclotomic PR I went for `Fintype.card { x // x âˆˆ rootsOfUnity n L } = n` and I wasn't really keen on that either. Do we need a predicate on integral domains (or comm cancel monoids with 0 or whatever) for "I have n n'th roots of unity"?
Would it work to just pass around `\exists x, IsPrimitiveRoot x n`?

Splitting the proof is surely a good idea, I am doing it.

Concerning the existence vs giving the witness, I guess this goes back to things like [IsPrimitiveRoot.card_rootsOfUnity'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/RootsOfUnity/Basic.html#IsPrimitiveRoot.card_rootsOfUnity'): if we refactor that file to use `âˆƒ Î¶, ...` then we will probably spot all places where we need to change it. I indeed think it is a good idea to use existence rather than the explicit witness (did I really ask to do the opposite? Sorry for that), but probably in another PR.
Sounds good to me.
I've golfed the proof using the explicit root of unity of order the `lcm` provided in #11235. The proof is indeed much shorter now, thanks!

I know I am late to the game, but several of these results seem to hold beyond the case of cyclotomic extensions of fields (not all of them, I agree, but the above inequality holds more generally). I have tried to generalize the proof to e.g. integral domains, and everything works but  at one point (the devil in the details...) where things become a bit messy since one has to trace back all places where the field assumption was not really needed. What is the general philosophy?

Note that `IsPrimitiveRoot.lcm_totient_le_finrank` (the inequality) does not assume the extension is cyclotomic. It is in this file because it uses cycolotomic extension in the proof.

Concerning the domain/field assumption, it seems to me that it is `IsCyclotomicExtension.finrank` that requires a field, and it can be trivial to generalize. I don't have much time now, but I can have a look tomorrow.

Mmm, already `IsPrimitiveRoot.powerBasis` wants a field. We may use [Algebra.adjoin.powerBasis'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Minpoly/IsIntegrallyClosed.html#Algebra.adjoin.powerBasis'), but it wants a noetherian ring. Maybe we can try the generalization in another PR?

Yes, it is indeed `IsCyclotomiExtension.finrank` that requires it (as per now). I certainly agree thtat the generalization should not be part of this PR, I was mainly trying to understand what were the objectives. But overall it certainly LGTM.

Here the goal is purely number theoretic: for example if `p=3`, then any unit in `â„¤[Î¶â‚ƒ]` is a root of unity (for example using Dirichlet... ok, this is maybe like using an atomic bomb, but still) and then we immediately (at least it is mathematically trivial to) get the list of the 6 units. And then we can prove kummer's lemma by hand.

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (hk : k â‰  0) (hk' : k' â‰  0) : IsPrimitiveRoot ```

```suggestion
is a primitive `n`-th root of unity, then there exists `r < n` such that `x = Î¶^r` or `x = -Î¶^r`. -/
```

```suggestion
/-- If `x` is a `k`-th root of unity in an `n`-th cyclotomic extension of â„š, where `n` is odd, and `Î¶`
```

```suggestion
/-- If `x` is a `k`-th root of unity in an `n`-th cyclotomic extension of â„š, where `n` is odd, and `Î¶`
```
Should this be `dvd_two_of_totient_le_one`? Right now it sounds like the totient divides something
Do the `symm`s cancel out?
This is changing the `Nat.lcm` to `PNat.lcm` and using `k`? I'd personally prefer something more explicit than `replace`
Done

```suggestion
  have key := IsPrimitiveRoot.lcm_totient_le_finrank hÎ¶ hroot
    (cyclotomic.irreducible_rat <| Nat.lcm_pos (Nat.pos_of_ne_zero hl.1) n.2)
```

```suggestion
    (hÎ¶ : IsPrimitiveRoot Î¶ n) (hx : x ^ (k : â„•) = 1) : âˆƒ r : â„•, x = (-1) ^ r * Î¶ ^ r :=  by
```

```suggestion
    âˆƒ r : â„•, r < n âˆ§ (x = Î¶ ^ r âˆ¨ x = -Î¶ ^ r) :=  by
```

I think this is more readable:
```suggestion
    (hk : k â‰  0) (hk' : k' â‰  0) :
    IsPrimitiveRoot
      (Î¶ ^ (k / Nat.factorizationLCMLeft k k') * Î¶' ^ (k' / Nat.factorizationLCMRight k k'))
      (Nat.lcm k k') := by
```

I think it makes sense to end the namespace `IsCyclotomicExtension` before your additions and change to `namespace IsPrimitiveRoot`, so as to avoid having to prefix everything with `_root_.IsPrimitiveRoot.`.
I've moved the results to the following namespace.
Is `(-1) ^ r * Î¶ ^ r` better than `(-Î¶) ^ r` (which is what I would tend to use)?
I guess it makes it easier to use in the next lemma, but it is only a question of moving the `rw [neg_pow]` from one proof to the other.
Could you convert that to an iff?
The `iff` is true only if `Î±` is finite. I've added it.
Isn't there a predicate for being of finite order? or for being a root of unity?
`orderOf x \ne 0` should work, but that's not very nice
We have `isOfFinOrder`, I've modified the statement to use it.
This is not the statement of the docstring
